reviewText:
Dick Tracy vs Cueball & Shadow Strikes

The Dick Tracy comic strip began around 1930 when Chester Gould created it for the Chicago Tribune. Its purpose was to influence public opinion to support the police in Chicago and elsewhere. It was liked by adults because of its cleverness and stories that appealed to the public. Its villains were famous for their distinctive features, a belief fostered by some criminologists that is obsolete. It met the wants of its audiences (fighting crime in the city). There was no mention of corrupt politicians or similar scandals. The Shadow was a popular radio program in the 19230s-1940s that featured Lamont Cranston, a man who worked undercover to fight crime. Refer to the individual reviews for more details.

Dick Tracy versus Cueball [1946] starts by investigating a murder on a ship. This leads to a stolen jewelry gang. [A small business operation.] Dick Tracy uses a lure to locate the murderer, who makes his final escape in a railroad yard.

The Shadow Strikes [1937] starts with a shot; a man cannot make a new will. Another shot eliminates an heir. If the will is destroyed the heirs will all get an equal share. There is conflict and a surprise confession to solve this crime.
